text: Concealer, lipstick, mascara on the counter. RUTH BADER GINSBURG (36) is applying blush. When she’s finished, she considers her reflection. She puts on A GOLD, SUNBURST PI And tries a smile. ..... But it looks forced. She drops i A breath. And she tries again. A different smile. And...
May it please the court. Not right yet. A smile. And...
Your honors and may it please the court... That’s not it either...
May it please the court. She looks herself in the eye one more time.
HEAR: Driving, martial music. Horns and drums. It’s the Crimson fight song “Ten Thousand Men of Harvard.” AS A MALE CHORUS joins...

Well groomed white MEN (20s) march through a quad. Into a impressive building with columned arches. “Ten Thousand Men of Harvard want victory today....” They're the future leaders of America. And in their well- dark suits, with their cocky grins, it’s clear they know “For they know that o’er old Eli, fair Harvard holds sway But amidst the pants and loafers -- GLIMPSE: a pair of hi heeled shoes, a skirt swaying, shoulder-length brown hair “So then we’ll conquer all old Eli’s men...”

AS THEY ENTER AN AUDITORIUM: She slows her step. Letting men pass... IT’S RUTH (23 here). Petite, lean and striking. She takes the size of the place, its grandeur. And is awed. “And when the game ends, we’ll sing again...” Proud, she continues down the center aisle. “Ten thousand men of Harvard gained victory today!” Ruth finds a seat. And as the crowd quiets, smiles to the she’s settling beside. He stares. Confused by her presenc IN FRONT: A line of seated professors. AMONG THEM: Profes Ernest Brown. ERWIN GRISWOLD (52, formidable) comes to a podium:
Settle down, please. ... Be seated.

GRISWOLD (CONT’D) My name is Erwin Griswold. I’m the dean of this place. ... Welcome to Harvard Law School. We have no glee club here. The work is hard. The load is heavy. ... Take a moment to look around you... Ruth does. There are over five hundred people in this gra room. Most of them are white. Only nine of them are women GRISWOLD (CONT’D) In this room are Rhodes and Fulbright scholars. Phi Beta Kappa members. Student body presidents. A Harvard Crimson football captain. Pats on the back for the smiling sports hero. GRISWOLD (CONT’D) Together, you will become lawyers. It is a privilege you share. And a responsibility that you accept. ... Consider: what does it mean to be a Harvard man? A Harvard man is intelligent, of course. But he is also tenacious. He is a leader devoted to the rule of law. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

He is mindful of his country. Loyal to tradition. And he is respectful and protective of our institutions. OFF RUTH: Determined. INT. GINSBURG HARVARD APARTMENT —- LATE DAY The garden apartment is small and uncluttered: mismatched furniture, books, baby toys and museum posters. IN THE BEDROOM: THE MARRIAGE OF FIGARO plays on a record. Ruth, in a slip, is considering the contents of her close One dress in hand, she pulls out another. She can’t decid She takes them with her... Out of the room. DOWN THE HALL THE LIVING ROOM empty, she enters THE ADJACENT KITCHEN:

(re: the dresses) Which one makes me look more like a Harvard man? MARTIN GINSBURG (24, classically handsome) is at the kitc table. Bouncing their daughter JANE (1) on his knee. He looks up from a textbook before him. Adoring.
I’m thrilled you look nothing like a Harvard man.
Seriously, you know how I am at these things. It’s the dean’s dinner, Marty. I need to make a good impression.
You will, Kiki (pr: Kick-EE). But it’s the other way around. You make the dress look good. She kisses him -- and Jane. Then notices Martin’s untouch plate of “food” on the table.
You barely touched your tuna casserole. I put onions in. They help, right? They don’t. As he forces down a forkful: (CONTINUED )
Yeah... Definitely.
(re: the dresses) I don’t like either of these. She breezes out of the room.

(to Jane) So. Where were we? ... Ah. (reading aloud to her) The Tax Code disallows some deductions held to be contrary to the public interest. (off Jane's babbling) Just wait. This is the good part. He eats a grape off her plate.

A grand room. Dignified and formal. MALE PROFESSORS in su chatting collegially. THE EIGHT OTHER WOMEN of the class 1959 (20s, intelligent, poised) are ingratiating themselv Ruth enters. A vision in her swing dress and pearls. And takes it all in: The room. The crowd. The chatter... The are proffering arms to the women. Forming a double-line t enter THE DINING ROOM... Before the doors, Dean Griswold and his wife, HARRIET GRISWOLD (52, on crutches, crippled by polio), are welcom their guests...
Welcome. ... Hello, Professor.
Harry. You're happy with the updated textbooks? ... Good. Ruth prepares herself... Then joins in.

Ruth eats her stewed chicken and lima beans with slow precision. She scans the room. They’re around a formal dining table: and women in alternating seats. Entrenched in conversatio Being served by Black Waiters. She eyes the women: Confident. Wise. With easy laughs. To her right: a YOUNG PROFESSOR faces away from her, ashi cigarette in the ashtray between him and Ruth, and talkin one of the women, EMILY:

He said, “Professor, have you corrected our papers?” I said, “Correcting them would take a lifetime. I’m merely grading them.” Emily laughs gregariously. DING-DING-DING. At the head of the table, Griswold TAPS H GLASS, rising. Ruth puts down her utensils neatly.

Esteemed colleagues. Ladies. This is only the sixth year women have had the privilege to earn a Harvard Law degree. This little soiree is our way of saying welcome. (pointing her out) My wife Harriet and I are glad all nine of you have joined us. APPLAUSE. Ruth is grateful. But notes that some professor are more enthusiastic than others. GRISWOLD (CONT’D) Let us go around the table. And each of the ladies, report who you are, where you’re from... And why you're occupying a place at Harvard that could have gone to a man. As Griswold sits, Ruth is disquieted. She and the other w exchange anxious glances. Harriet singles out the closest
Why don’t you get us started, dear? One of Ruth’s CLASSMATES rises. White knuckling her chair (CONTINUED )

I’m Hennie Callaghan. Father’s a lawyer back in Minneapolis. He used to give me drafts of contracts to use for drawing paper. At some point, I got more interested in reading them than drawing on them. In a few years, it’s going to be Callaghan and Callaghan.
That was fine. Next? EMILY’s turn. She rises.
Emily Hicks. Hello. Connecticut. When I finished Mt. Holyoke, my mother wanted me to get married. But I didn’t want to do THAT. And I didn’t want to be a teacher or a nurse. So when I--

Ha. That’s not a very good reason. Ruth watches Emily slump into her seat -- mortified. All land on Ruth. Including Griswold’s. She stands... And knocks over the Young Professor’s ash tray. It lands a heavy thud. Ruth stares at the ash and butts on the rug When she looks up -- she eyes them all. The anxious women The men watching her. Emily controlling her frustration. Griswold is waiting...
I’m Ruth Ginsburg, from Brooklyn.
And why are you here Miss Ginsburg?

Mrs. Ginsburg, actually. My husband Marty is in the second-year class. aenee I’m at Harvard to learn about his work. So I can be a more patient and understanding wife. Emily laughs. Several others gasp. And on Griswold’s face plain dislike. OFF RUTH: Seeing it.
Ruth. Home from dinner. Rubbing her sore feet.
Come to dinner. The beans will be boiled. The chicken will be stewed. And you will be grilled. ... We came to Harvard to be lawyers. Why else? Martin, in an undershirt, climbs off the bed.
It was an asinine question.
I couldn't just ignore it! But the way he looked at me. Now he’1l never take me seriously.
You're smarter than everyone here. You'll be better prepared. Just stand up and say what you know. In this place, that’s all the matters. She turns her back: Unzip me.
In my experience even small mistakes are glaring when you stick out. The dress falls to the floor. And he turns her around...
Then you’re lucky. Because you’re very short. She laughs. Despite herself.
Oh, yeah? Why don’t you come down here and say that to my face? She pulls him into a kiss. Flirty. Fun... He lifts her. buries her face in his neck, as they fall onto the bed.
She The grand room is laid out like a Roman theater. Portrait alumni stare down: Holmes, Brandeis, Frankfurter... (CONTINUED )
Ruth sits in the first row. Surrounded by men. A textboo the desk: Introduction to Contracts. At nine-thirty precisely, PROF. ERNEST BROWN (50) enters. begins lecturing.

I’m Professor Brown. This is Introduction to Contracts. Hawkins versus McGee. Ruth’s hand flies up. Along with several others. Brown ey one student not raising his hand -- and finds him on a hu seating chart with passport-size photos...
State the case please, Mr. Pruitt. PRUITT adjusts his tie as he rises.
Uh, good morning. I’m Donald Pruitt. I’m really honored to be here with--
Hawkins v McGee. As Pruitt flips through his textbook:
Hawkins v McGee. It’s uh-- a fascinating breach-of-contract case that-- (found it) Oh, right! Charles Hawkins hurt his hand. And McGee--
Can someone help him, please? As Pruitt deflates into his seat, a smug classmate, FITZPATRICK, sees Ruth’s hand go up first. He raises his well. Brown looks at Ruth. Checks his seating chart...
Yes? ... Mr. Fitzpatrick. Fitzpatrick rises, giving Ruth a look...
It was Charles’s son who hurt his hand. ... Electrocution burn. (CONTINUED)
And on what point does the case turn, Mr. Fitzpatrick?

McGee promised to fix the hand... Ruth frowns. She knows Fitzpatrick’s not quite right. But notices that no one else seems bothered by it. FITZPATRICK (CONT’D) .--by performing a skin graft. But McGee wasn’t very familiar with the procedure. And the results weren’t quite what he’d planned. Ruth can’t let it lie. She decides to raise her hand.
A question already, Mrs. Ginsburg?

(rising) A correction, Professor Brown. McGee did not simply promise to fix George Hawkins’s hand. He promised, quote: a one hundred-percent good hand. Pruitt flips pages in his textbook, trying to catch up.
That's the same thing.
Is it? What say you, Mrs. Ginsburg?
It is not. Words matter. McGee grafted skin from Hawkins’s chest. Not only did this fail to fix the scarring, he had chest hair growing on his palm.
Proving that a hand with a burn is worth two with a bush. LAUGHTER FROM THE CLASS.
The Court denied Hawkins damages-- (CONTINUED )
Hawkins did get damages! The court said he could keep up to five hundred dollars--

If I may finish: Hawkins was denied damages for pain and suffering. (as Fitzpatrick sits) The New Hampshire Supreme Court ruled he was entitled to damages only based on the expected result of the contract being fulfilled. Brown, sliding down his reading glasses, measures up Ruth over the frames. Pruitt, still flipping pages, is frantic

So if Dr. McGee had set realistic expectations, instead of making grand promises, Hawkins’s award likely would have been less. A pair of men share a glance: “Ball-buster."” Pruitt give Ruth has silenced the room.
Was that an answer, Mrs. Ginsburg, or a filibuster? As the class laughs, Ruth sits. Holding steady.

Couches and endless book shelves. Warm light through the windows. Students study, read, and hang out. AND IN ONE N Emily is on a couch with another female FRIEND (20s). Mar and TWO OTHER GUYS (20s) are on another. Beers all around Ruth stands before them... THEY’RE PLAYING CHARADES:
Movie... Four words... Second word. Ruth takes a swig of her beer. Then holds up seven finger
Seven.
Fourth word. Ruth thinks a beat... then starts scratching. The Men LAU (CONTINUED )
Ape! Gorilla!
Monkey!
Monkey Business! Ruth waves them off. Builds her courage -- despite the passing gawkers... And does her best Marilyn Monroe. Posi Back arched. Butt out.
Monkey on my back! THE MEN LAUGH MORE. Martin laughs so hard his stomach hur As Ruth reminds them: Second word. Seven.
Seven Brides for Seven Brothers.
What’s that have to do with monkeys?
(eye on his watch) Annnnnd....
Oh! Oh! Oh!
Time! The Seven Year Itch!
Yes! As Martin gets up and kisses her:
Ruthless Ruthy strikes again! She jabs him in the gut playfully with an elbow.
Okay. Next round is riding on you. As Martin picks his clue from a hat:
Don’t worry. He’s very good. (CONTINUED)
And she dumped a guy once for being bad at charades.
You didn’t really?
It was a manifestation... of his being an idiot.
(to Guy 2) Don’t worry. I’m comfortable being smarter than you.
Oh, thank you. LAUGHTER ALL AROUND.
Everyone ready? And... Go! Martin begins.
A song. Martin curls his lip, shakes his arms, and gyrates his hi They enjoy his spot-on impression -- especially Ruth.
By Elvis.
Three words. ... First word. He points to a blue pillow:
Pillow! Chair!
Blue! Blueberry Hill!
That’s Fats Domino.
Third word. Pointing to his feet, Martin does a bit of fancy footwork (CONTINUED )
Nice moves! Martin winces, clutching his belly. And cries out.
No sound effects! Blue Suede Shoes!
Marty, you’re a lightweight. Ruth knows something’s wrong. She runs to Martin. Going t her knees. Cradling him...
Marty? ... Marty! Martin’s looking up at her. Pain written on his face.
He needs help. Somebody help! As Ruth’s world slows and the sound fades:
Someone call an ambulance!
Marty. I’m right here. I have you.
Hard floors and harder chairs. Ruth sits alone...

It’s crowded. Ruth tries not to watch the other worrying families. A man soothes his wife... Fewer people waiting. Ruth still waiting. A mother reprim her son in harsh whispers... Fewer still. Ruth still waiting. The misbehaving boy is asleep on his mother’s lap... The sky is lightening out the window. The few people left sleeping. Except Ruth. Still up. Still waiting. She gets up...  14 INT. NURSES’ STATION / CORRIDOR - EARLY MORNING Ruth approaches and tries to get the attention of TWO NUR - talking among themselves:
Excuse me. Excuse me? I’d like to see the doctor who-- One gestures for her to wait. She does for a frustrated beat. Then notices AN EMERGENCY ROOM DOCTOR (30) DOWN THE HALL. Ruth pursues him...
Doctor? ... Doctor? He turns with a look that says, “I don’t have time for th
Yes?
You examined my husband. I’m wondering when you think he’1l be able to leave. I need to call the sitter.
What’s the patient’s name?
Ginsburg. Martin.
Right. Ginsburg... He’s not going home tonight.
Excuse me?
We have more tests to run.
What kind of tests? Her voice stops him in his tracks.
Various kinds. He’s gonna be with us a while. (CONTINUED )
What tests are you running on my husband?
There was a shadow on his X-ray that--
What kind of shadow?! I need to see him!
Mrs. Ginsburg. You're getting yourself worked up. Go home. Get some rest. We’ll know more in a few days. ..... If you’ll excuse me. He leaves her. In the busy hallway. Uncertain and scared.
Ruth enters. The sound of the door wakes up Emily, on the couch. Still in the same dress as during charades.
Thank you so much.
Ruth. Of course. Jane was a doll. She's blissfully asleep. .... How is he?
Fine. I’m sure he'll be fine. Emily hesitates to believe her. Then gives her a long hug

Call any time. Okay? She leaves Ruth. ... Alone. And painfully aware of it. Ruth turns on the record player, lifts the needle. AND ST Her gaze shifts to the collection of FAMILY PHOTOS on the credenza beside the record player. TO HER MOTHER. Posing young Ruth. Supportive. Uncompromising. Strong. Wearing t same sunburst pin Ruth wore in the opening scene.
Ruth lowers the needle at last. Static gives way to SOFT OPERA. A breath. Then Ruth walks DOWN THE EMPTY HALL... (CONTINUED )
16 TO JANE’S BEDROOM. As the girl sleeps, Ruth watches her. Keeping her fear and doubt at bay. ENTERING HER AND MARTIN'S BEDROOM, she collapses atop the covers. And curls up alone...

Bright. Antiseptic. A TICKING CLOCK. Martin is hooked up glass IV. Reading a textbook in bed. In a chair beside hi Ruth has a law book as well. But she’s watching him. Wait Her gaze shifts -- to an empty hospital food tray...

At least you got a break from my cooking. He looks to her. And they laugh -- nervously. DOCTOR WYLAND LEADBETTER (50) enters. Clean-shaven, in a tie, vest and white coat, full of genial self-confidence.
Good afternoon.
Dr. Leadbetter.
Hey, Doc. As he pulls up a chair, he glances at Martin's textbook:
Fundamental Principles of Corporate Taxation: Addressing the Challenges of Today’s Regulatory Environment. I thought medical books were dry. He sits. And prepares himself to deliver the news...
It’s as we feared. Ruth and Martin take the blow.
Marty you’re young, and we caught it early. We’ve pioneered a treatment here. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
17 DR. LEADBETTER (CONT’D) It entails multiple surgeries, each followed by a course of radiation. It’'s-- well, it’s unpleasant, but--
What does that mean?
On top of the pain of surgery, the radiation will leave you exhausted, nauseous. Prone to infection.
(off Leadbetter’s look) Her mother died of cervical cancer.
With the new treatment, there’s a chance you could go on to live a healthy, normal life -- as if this never happened.
What kind of “a chance”? (off his hesitation) Dr. Leadbetter, we’d rather know what we're facing.
The survival rate for testicular cancer has been about five percent. It hangs there for a beat...
Thank you for the honesty. I think.

(leaving) I’1l let you two talk. In the wreckage of his wake: a heavy silence... Martin tries to make sense of it. Ruth stifles her tears. They can’t even look at each other... Until Ruth takes Martin’s hand. Pulling him back into the present. They watch one another a beat... She rises. And sits on the bed beside him. Their eyes loc
I’m sorry. (CONTINUED )
18 Slowly she lies next to him. They hold each other. Watchi one another. The clear path of their future lost in a haz

We’re never giving up. Keep working. Keep studying. Jane will have her father. And you will be a lawyer. I am spending my life with you, Martin Ginsburg. EXT. HARVARD CAMPUS — DAY Bare trees. Snow flurries. ... Ruth rushes through. She’s running late.
Judicial consistency...
PROFESSOR FREUND (48), black hair, broad, lectures before full class. His voice resonant:
The doctrine of stare decisis comes from English Common Law... The door CREAKS. And Ruth enters. As Freund continues lecturing, he watches her find a seat in back.
Which also provides the first examples of circumstances where precedents may be overturned. Judges are bound... Excuse me. May I help you? She rises tentatively.
I’m Martin Ginsburg’s wife. I’1l be attending his classes for him. Freund seems surprised by it. His students are impressed.
In addition to your own? The look in her eye leaves no room for negotiation. Freun moved. He resumes his lecture without further objection.. (CONTINUED )
Judges are bound by precedent. But cannot ignore cultural change. Ruth sits and begins taking notes.
A Court ought not be affected by the weather of the day, but will be by the climate of the era.
(weakly) Wait. Wait. Say that again...
AT THE KITCHEN TABLE: Ruth sits before a typewriter. From vantage point, through the opening between rooms, she can only see half of Martin -- LYING ON THE LIVING ROOM COUCH
(reading her notes aloud) A Court ought not be affected by the weather of the day, but will be by the climate of the era.
You’re sure that’s what he said? She leans to the side to give him a look that says “Are y kidding?” His chalky skin is blotched in sweat.
(off her look) Of course. He closes his eyes and catches his breath.
The law is never finished. It is a work in progress. And ever will be. As he dictates, Ruth types...

Brown v Board of Education, parenthesis 1954, was the most revolutionary Supreme Court case of the last century... WAAAAH! Somewhere in the apartment, JANE CRIES. Ruth type the last few letters as she rises... (CONTINUED )
20 Martin continues, AS SHE PASSES HIM:
Representing Oliver Brown, et. al.
I’m not listening. SHE HEADS FOR JANE’S ROOM, but Martin’s on a roll:
Thurgood Marshall educated the Court about the burdens created by segregation-- IN JANE’S ROOM, the crying drowns Martin out.
Sweetheart. What’s wrong? Ruth scoops her up. And her cries fade to a whimper. Ruth takes Jane with her back to THE LIVING ROOM... en route t

Okay. Brown v. Board of Ed. Go. Silence. It stops her. Clutching Jane, she turns to find Martin still as stone. She approaches him... Martin’s asleep. His breathing shallow. Jane still in her arms, Ruth returns to THE KITCHEN. She takes a sip of coffee. Then removes the page from the typewriter, stacks it with others, and puts them all into folder -- labelled “Martin.” She opens another folder: “Ruth.” Loads a half-typed page into the machine. And resumes her work in the quiet dark.
One... Two...
Campus is in bloom. Ruth and Martin walk with Jane (3 now holding both their hands and swinging between them....
...Threeeeee!
Again! Again! (CONTINUED )
(reading Martin’s look) Daddy needs a rest, sweetheart.
(disappointed) Okay. When she runs ahead, Martin watches her.
One day that little angel is going to slam a door in our faces and tell us we're ruining her life. Ruth appreciates the observation.
I shouldn’t have taken the job.
It’s a great firm. And New York is the center of the legal universe. You've earned it.
You earned it. I just survived. I don’t want be apart from either of you.

You won't be. I won’t allow it. ... I’1l convince him. INT. DEAN GRISWOLD’S OFFICE - DAY A room with history. Daunting. Regal. Griswold sits at hi desk. Ruth, tiny in an oversized chair, looks him in the
You want a Harvard degree, though you plan to finish your coursework at... Columbia? You would be well served to remember, Mrs. Ginsburg, how fortunate you are to be here.
Dean Griswold, between the first and third year of law school, which is the more substantive? The more critical? (CONTINUED )
The first. Of course.
Yet when someone transfers in as a second-year student -- having taken those more important classes elsewhere -- he’s allowed a degree.
That ’s--
I’ve been here two years. I’m first in my class.
There is no reason why your husband cannot provide for you while you and the child remain in Boston.
Last year, John Sumner was allowed to finish his coursework in Baltimore. Three years ago, Roy Paxton-—-
Very different cases.
How are they differ--
Mrs. Ginsburg. You have no compelling need to transfer.
Marty could relapse! The doctors say at any time. He puts a good face on it, but I can see it. He’s scared. Dean Griswold, this is my family. Griswold is sympathetic for a beat...

Nonetheless. We each have our responsibilities. And mine is to protect the distinction of a Harvard degree. I can’t force you to stay. But I won’t reward you for leaving, either. The argument lost.  23

Ruth. Bearing her disappointment. Comes out of the buildi For a beat, she watches Martin and Jane playing tag among trees. Until Martin stops to catch his breath. And notice her. Smiling, he waves. Ruth forces a smile. And waves back. FADE TO BLACK.

A brownstone on a quiet side street. Ruth comes out in sm suit. Determined and bold. She heads down the street. And around the corner. REVEALI NEW YORK, NY -- in autumnal red and gold. Vibrant, bustli and alive.
Ruth goes through a revolving door into an impressive LOB She enters an elevator full of men in suits.
Jesus, Mary and Joseph.
GREENE (45), a big man, a street-wise lawyer, is reading Ruth’s resume. SOUNDS OF CONSTRUCTION outside.
Graduating top of your class. Law Review at Harvard AND COLUMBIA?! I didn’t even know that was possible.
Thank you, Mr. Greene. I’ve worked hard.
You want some white-shoe firm. Big- money cases, complex legal maneuvers. (CONTINUED )
No, I think Bibler and Greene would be a perfect fit. You handled the Mercer bankruptcy last year, and--
C’mon. How many have you been to? With a look, she deflects.
They all turned you down right? How many? Ten?
Twelve.
A woman. A mother. A Jew, to boot. I'm impressed that many let you through the door.
One sent me to interview for the Secretarial Pool.
Hal

Another told me I’d be too busy at bake sales to be effective. One partner closes clients in the locker room at his club -- so he said I'd be out of the loop. Last week I was told women are too emotional to be lawyers. Then, that same afternoon, that a woman graduating top of her class must be “a real ball-buster,” and wouldn’t make a good colleague. I was asked when I’d have my next baby, and whether I keep Shabbat. One interviewer told me I have a sterling resume, but they hired a woman last year, and what in the world would they want with two of us? Unburdened, she lets out her breath. And grows embarrasse Greene’s sardonic chuckle says he gets it:
You must be livid. (CONTINUED )
25 She is.
My mother taught me not to give way to emotions.
Bull shit! You’re angry. Good! Use it. I have to say, Mrs. Ginsburg, I'm impressed. A glimmer of hope. Ruth grabs for it...

Mr. Greene. I want to be a lawyer. I want to represent clients before the court in pursuit of justice. (re: her resume) You can see I worked hard through school. I did everything I was supposed to, and I excelled. I swear it: I’1l do the same for you. Greene takes a moment to think... As he does, his gaze dr over the contours of her body. Ruth tenses.
Thing is... We’re a close-knit firm. Almost like family. And well-- the wives, they get jealous. Ruth stares him down. Fighting her building fury.
Ruth back on the street. Stunned... She slows. Almost to a stop. Diminished... New York continues its perpetual movement around her with notice.

It’s mostly the same furniture, art and books -- moved to new city. One addition: an original opera poster from Rom Ruth is on the couch with Jane (4 now) in her lap. They’r reading the Marcia Brown illustrated edition of CINDERELL (CONTINUED )
The prince would marry her whose foot would fit the little slipper. First they tried it on the-- They hear the FRONT DOOR OPEN. As Martin finds them:
Ruth? Kiki?
Daddy!
(sweeping her up) Hi sweetie. He notes a bottle of champagne on ice near the couch. He kisses
You got the job! Are they giving you a corner office, or will they make you jump through hoops first? her.
It’s not at Bibler and Greene. I wasn’t what they were looking for.
I don’t-- Then what’s the firm?
Clyde Ferguson left his professorship at Rutgers.
Kiki.
They haven’t found another black man to replace him, so someone decided a woman would be the next- best thing.
There are more firms. You can’t give up. This is the biggest city in the most litigious country in the history of the world. You can still-- She shuts him up with a kiss. (CONTINUED )
Marty. I got a job. Open the champagne. For a beat, he searches her face...
Okay. Okay! Let’s celebrate. As he opens the bottle:
Y'know what? I think this is better. I do. Ruth puts on a record. THE MARRIAGE OF FIGARO OVERTURE begins.
You won't be beholden to a firm. There won’t be partners breathing down your neck. A professor can represent any client she wants. POP! ... The bottle open, he pours.
So long as they don’t mind a lawyer who’s never actually practiced law. (re: champagne) Thank you.
(a toast) Hooray for Mommy!
Hooray for Mommy!
... Hooray for Mommy. She takes a drink. BLACK. HEAR: SCREAMING. CURSING. A MASS OF FURY...
Early fall. STUDENT PROTESTORS (20s) throng the urban boulevards around the MAIN PLAZA STEPS -- across the stre from Rutger’s Law School. Seething. Screaming. (CONTINUED )
28 And scorched by late-summer heat. They wave placards: ‘Impeach Nixon’; ‘End the War’. They’re surrounded by A CORDON OF CAMPUS POLICE OFFICERS.
ON THE STEPS: students hoist enlarged photos of the KENT STATE MASSACRE. A PROTEST LEADER has a microphone:
Blood flowed at Kent State. Those Guardsmen shot blindly into the crowd. And for what? Was anyone armed?
No! Professor Ruth Bader Ginsburg (36 now) approaches the thr This isn’t “Occupy” anything. It’s Tahrir Square...

No! They murdered them. Murdered them for protesting Nixon’s illegal and immoral and grotesque war in Vietnam. Ruth wedges her way INTO THE CROWD: Student-Protestors al around. Taller than her. Men, women, white, black. SCREAM WITH RAGE. She sees The Protest Leader over their shoulde
And now-- Now we’re told there will be NO PROSECUTIONS! Are we gonna stand for it?
No!
Are we gonna die in Vietnam?
Hell no! We won’t go! Hell no! We won’t go! As Ruth pushes toward ACKERSON HALL: Campus Police hold t Students back with billy clubs. She’s jostled. And ignore  29

My client’s name is Charles Moritz.
That’s cute.

He hired a nurse who helps care for his mother. But he was denied a caregiver deduction on his taxes. Kenyon does the calculation. It takes her a beat -- but j a beat -- to put it together. Kenyon stops.
He’s never been married. You found a bachelor taking care of his mother at home? .... The judges will be repulsed by him.
Feeling anything is a start.
+. What did you say your name was?
Ruth Bader Ginsburg. She and Kenyon watch one another for an extended beat.
Well... Sorry Professor Ginsburg. Maybe someday. But the country isn’t ready. Change minds first. Then change the law. ... (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
60 If you'll excuse me, the mayor’s decided to rename the neighborhood, so now a developer's kicking thirty families out of a building he abandoned ten years ago. As she heads to the stairwell...
.-. SoHo. Who’s ever heard of a ridiculous thing? Ruth and Jane share a look: Whoa.
It’s raining hard as Ruth and Jane exit. such They open their umbrellas. Ruth looks back the way they came. Then points Jane in the other direction.
Let’s catch a cab. They start walking.
I know she's your personal hero and all. But she's kind of a bitch.

No. She’s formidable. ... Dorothy Kenyon has been fighting for Civil Rights and Women’s Rights and Labor Rights her entire career. She didn’t always win. But she made damn sure she was taken seriously. The rain is pelting down. Ruth and Jane take cover under scaffolding. A cab passes, but its dome light is off. The lower their umbrellas.
She didn’t help you. ... What are you going to do?
It’s the right cause. It’s the right client. But women have been losing this same argument for over a century.
Well... just because you lost a hundred years before you started is no reason not to try to win. Ruth considers it... And realizes: (CONTINUED )
Jane. That was incredibly wise.
Do you know who said it first? (Ruth doesn’t) Atticus Finch. In Ruth’s look: “Touché.” Across the street, two CON ED WORKERS SHOUT and WHISTLE a lasciviously.
Lookin’ good, ladies. We'll warm you up... if you’re getting wet.
(checking for another cab) It's okay. Just ignore them.
Too good for us, huh? Bitches! Jane SHOUTS back at them.
Real nice. You kiss your mother with that mouth? Asshole. That shuts the Workers up. Jane sees Ruth’s surprise.
Mom. You can’t just let boys talk to you like that. At that moment, Jane sees a vacant cab approaching. She dashes out fearlessly and YELLS:

The cab BRAKES sharply. Ruth starts out after her, but st mid-street. Jane’s at the cab door. Ruth looks around at the constructions workers tearing do buildings, wild posting for a Joni Mitchell concert; a co making out; sexy women on a billboard...
Mom, c’mon. (to the TAXI DRIVER) Yeah, yeah. Hold on a second. She returns to her mother. She’s not sure what’s going on
He’s not gonna wait forever. You're getting soaked. (CONTINUED )
Twenty years. (a beat) Look at you. It may as well be two hundred.
You lost me.
It’s only twenty years since I was your age. Back then girls were told: “Be a lady.” “Speak when spoken to.” “Respect your elders.” Jane's getting where her mom is headed...
Now it’s ‘Don’t trust anyone over thirty!’
They taught me how to curtsy in school. (laughs ) I couldn't go out wearing pants.
I’m not even wearing a bra. The cabbie HONKS impatiently.
You are a liberated, fearless young woman. Twenty years ago, you couldn’t have been who you are today. (a beat) Dorothy Kenyon’s wrong. The times have already changed.
Ruth. Alone. Consulting a book. Hunched over a legal pad. Writing. Crossing out. And starting again. OUTSIDE THE DOOR: a Janitor buffs the hallway floors. (CONTINUED )
It’s what Professor Freund said at Harvard...
Ruth’s standing at the counter. Eating leftovers. Martin reading the typed notes. Concerned...
“RA court ought not be affected by the weather of the day. But will be by the climate of the era.”
Okay... So we’re not re-fighting the old cases.
We're arguing the precedents should no longer apply.
But Ruth, Freund was talking about Brown v. Board of Ed. That was a once-in-a-generation case.
And we're the next generation. OFF MARTIN: impressed.
Ruth is dictating her notes to a department secretary, MILLICENT (28, sultry), who is typing them up.
Martin is on the couch, writing notes on Ruth’s typed wor IN THE BACKGROUND: Jane is laying out dinner on the table Ruth is on the floor, playing checkers with James.
King me!  64

On the wall over her desk, Ruth tacks up the same note ca SEE: OTHERS. AND NEWSPAPER CLIPPINGS. It’s the outline of argument. Martin’s on the bed, surrounded by books, writing his tax section of the brief.
CLOSE ON TYPEWRITER KEYS STRIKING THE PAPER: “Changes in societal attitudes.” ... “Unalterable biological traits.”

Ruth’s added a coffee pot to the room. Some of her class with her. They’re passing books, newspapers, journals -- Chinese food cartons -- between them. Animated. Discussin OVER THIS, START TO HEAR: MILLICENT’S TYPING...

text: Ruth and Martin walking -- dressed in overcoats:
Our client is a man. We can’t lose sight of that. Men are also harmed by these stereotypes. Boys who are told they’re not supposed to be nurses, or teachers, or--
Cook dinner for their families.
We’re counting on you, too.
Ruth and Martin are cuddled on the couch. Writing notes o their work... Noticing one another, they stop. Kiss... And resume worki THE TYPING CONTINUES. LOUDER STILL...  65
Millicent is typing up their hand-written pages... She pulls out the final page. INT. RUTGERS LAW SCHOOL - RUTH’S OFFICE - LATER Millicent enters -- the typed Moritz Brief in hand:
Professor Ginsburg? I finished typing the brief.
(accepting it) You're a saint, Millicent.

May I make an observation? ... It’s just... I’m typing your brief. And jumping out all over it is, well... sex-sex-sex-sex-sex-sex. It reeks of hormones and backseats and-- You know how men are. Maybe you should try a less distracting word. She and Ruth exchange a look... MILLICENT (CONT’D) Maybe... gender?
You realize that means...
That’s no problem. I’m happy to type it again. Off Ruth: END SEQUENCE.
Mel hurries down the hallway, chatting with a LAWYER.
Guessing does me no good. I need to know how many people were actually turned away from the polls. (CONTINUED )
The Affiliate still hasn’t sent the list.

Call Brian Tanner. Remind him, please, that we’re on the same team. And tell him if he doesn’t start acting like it, I’1l come to Wisconsin and rip his God-damn throat out myself! As he opens his OFFICE DOOR:
Melvin. Didn’t your mother ever teach you to clean your room?
She's sitting behind his desk. Reading a newspaper -- THE IDAHO STATESMAN. Mel, surprised, enters and closes the do
Ms. Kenyon. Is it time for your annual dusting-off already? Kenyon laughs. As she folds her newspaper...
In 1776, Abigail Adams wrote her husband a letter. “As you write this new constitution,” she said, “Remember the ladies.” Know what the bastard went ahead and did?
I can guess. She slams the paper down, the article oriented toward him “COURT FINDS FOR CECIL REED.”
The Idaho Statesman? You need a hobby.
These poor people. Sally and Cecil Reed. Divorced. Their son committed suicide, and both parents want to administer his estate. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
In Idaho the law says that in this situation, males must be preferred to females. Why? ‘Cause men are better at math. She taps the newspaper article with her finger.
The Idaho Supreme Court just said that is perfectly legal. With some effort, she gets up. Taking her over-sized bag her. As she does:
Dorothy. I’ve got student protestors in jail in California. I’ve got schools in Mississippi that still refuse to desegrega--
Eh, you’re a sissy. The Board threatened to can you ‘cause you stood up for draft dodgers, and your tail’s been between your legs ever since.
That’s not-- I don’t have the resources to take this on.

I’ve seen you stand up to the might of government with sling and stone for what you know is right. And kid, I loved ya for it. They’re not gonna fire you, Mel. The board’s a bunch of tired old fools, and they don’t have the nerve to do it. I should know; I’m one of ‘em. She takes his hand.
John Adams forgot the ladies. And it’s time the ACLU got back in the fight. With a look, he concedes.
Good. (digging into her bag) Now here’s where you start. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

A case headed for the tenth circuit. Professor out of Rutgers. Smart cookie. She presents him with a copy of Ruth’s Moritz Brief... He looks at it. Surprised. Then his surprise turns into clarity -- he glances at the newspaper still on his desk:
("of course”) Ruth. She pats him on the cheek.
You’re a good boy.
The Fourteenth Amendment is written on the board. Ruth, before her class, underlines the Equal Protection Clause.
But nowhere does the Constitution say the federal government must treat people equally. What did the Court say about that? Mrs. Parker.
That the Due Process Clause implies that Equal Protection applies to the federal government as well.
Can you cite the case? Parker hesitates. Unsure. ... REVEAL:
Bolling v Sharpe. 347 U.S. 497. He’s in the doorway. A briefcase in hand.
Decided in conjunction with Brown v Board of Ed in 1954, Bolling desegregated Washington, D.C.’s public schools. Chief Justice Warren, writing for the Court. .... How about it, Teach? Do I get an A?
INT. DINER — DAY Ruth and Mel with coffee. Only Mel is eating pie. He reac into his bag -- and drops Ruth’s brief between them. An accusation in his eyes.
It was well played Ruth, sending your work to Kenyon.
(playing innocent) I thought she might have advice.
Cut the shit. Just don’t play games with me again. They stare each other down for a beat...
What did you think of the brief?
(admitting it) It’s a compelling argument. Brilliantly reasoned. These days more women than ever are working. And why not? We have pre-schools and washing machines and cheap contraceptives.
Times have changed.

But there’s a glaring problem... In the unlikely event that you win this thing -- what’s the remedy? The Court takes away the Caregiver Deduction from everyone -- including working mothers. And then you've done more harm than good.
No. Do you remember Justice Harlan’s opinion last June in Welsh v United States? (CONTINUED )
(getting it, impressed) He said laws could be extended, when doing so would be closer to the legislature's intent than overturning would be.
We're adding one more section to the brief, urging The Court to extend the law -- to include Charlie as well as everyone else. 70 Mel runs through the argument in his mind. It could work.
I still say I'd rather be a woman in America than a black man. Or a socialist. Or religious minority... But the ACLU will put its name on your brief.
We appreciate your support. She gives it a beat...
Now let’s talk about you taking on Reed v Reed. (off his look) All men in Idaho are better at math?! It’s a perfect example of--
Quit while you’re ahead, Kiki. One case. That’s all you get. As he goes for his wallet:

The Moritz argument works just as well for a female client. And Reed’s a state supreme court case. Which means the US Supreme Court must hear the appeal. (he’s ignoring her) Call Sally Reed’s lawyer, Mel.
I told you, I’m not starting another fifty-year battle. I'd worry about defending my own case, if I were you. He tosses some cash on the table. And rises to go. (CONTINUED )

I expect to see your Remedy argument before you submit to the Tenth Circuit. And I want to be there when you practice your oral arguments. (before she can protest) We're holding a moot court. That’s not negotiable.
(relenting) When?
As soon as we get the government's response brief.
Imposing, limestone facade -- gray in the winter-morning light. Over the entry: “Justice is founded in the rights bestowed by nature upon man.”

..-A pig ‘aint good for nothing but sitting in its own filth. INT. DOJ - TAX DIVISION - BOZARTH’S CUBICLE - DAY JIM BOZARTH (26), a Government Lawyer, is full of airy, likeable, college-boy confidence. In his uncluttered cubi a photo of his wife and a University of Texas coffee mug. He’s yukking it up with A COLLEAGUE (25):
It’s the first rule of barbecue. You start with a cow.
Well, you could try up in Columbia Heights, if not for... you know, the riots.

For a slab of beef cooked low and slow? I'll pack my ..45. GLADYS (55) approaches before him with a file cart. A reliable cog in the machine of government. She hands him brief. And a clipboard. (CONTINUED )
Bozarth. You finished a case today. As Bozarth’s Colleague takes his leave, she passes Bozart his new assignment...

Sign for your next brief. INSERT: Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals / Charles Moritz v Commissioner of Internal Revenue / Authors - Ruth Bader Ginsburg; Martin Ginsburg; Melvin Wulf, Legal Director, A Bozarth lets out a long whistle.
10th Circuit Court of Appeals. Know who I am, Gladys?
Sure do. You’re the kid who’s going to sign my form.
(as he does -- grinning) I’m a guy moving up in the world. He settles in, feet on the desk -- and opens the brief.
In the meantime, the chief best not catch you with your feet on that desk. He takes them down. And re-opens the brief.
Howdy, Mr. Moritz. And what can your Uncle Sam do for you today?
Brief in hand, Bozarth heads down a hallway to a closed d marked “Special Attorney / Tax Division”. Stops. Prepares himself. ... THEN KNOCKS.

-.. What is it?  73 INT. DOJ - BROWN’S OFFICE - LATER The room is utilitarian. Straight lines and right angles. With an orderly and organized charm that’s inviting. (Professor) Brown is 65 now. Dignified. Finished to a hig polish. He’s at his desk reading the brief. Bozarth watch
You can’t make a constitutional challenge to the Tax Code. Right?
(still reading) It’s a stretch.
And who’s ever heard of ‘gender discrimination?’ Brown gives him a look. Then finishes reading.
These folks are runnin’ at Hell with a bucket of water.
Case law is filled with challenges that could not be made... Until they were. I’m putting Murphy on writing our response brief.
With due respect, Mr. Brown--

It isn’t personal, Bozarth. But if we're not careful, this appeal will cast a cloud of unconstitutionality over every federal law that differentiates between men and women. I need someone more seasoned on it. For Bozarth, it’s a body blow. Brown picks up his phone..
Could you get me the Solicitor General, please? Bozarth summons his courage.
I pulled the file. I deserve the chance. Murphy’s a weak sister. (CONTINUED )
74 Brown gives him a dismissive look. Bozarth leans in. Firm:

I know how to win this case, sir. Better than Murphy. Better than anyone. You need me on this appeal. Brown stares. A bit impressed. A bit dubious... Before he decide, someone picks up on the other end of the line.
(eyes still on Bozarth) This is Brown. I need to see him.
A cold day. The ground dusted with snow. But (Dean) Erwin Griswold doesn’t seem to notice. He’s 67 now, and Nixon’s Solicitor General. Brown and Bozarth walk with him...
For God’s sake! Where does it end? Gender equality as a civil right?!
When everyone's aggrieved and a victim. It’s what the ACLU does. Divide the country into smaller and smaller subgroups.
Ginsburg... Cancer, right? And the wife. Very demanding.
But smart.
Ten years. Ten years I fought to enroll women at Harvard Law. The faculty, the university -- even my wife warned me it could come back to haunt me. Now this is the thanks I get.

Erwin, we could settle. Martin Ginsburg was one of my best students. A practical young man. I can call him, tell him we'll let the man have his money. And we go our separate ways. Griswold thinks about it for a beat... (CONTINUED )
No. ... No. We settle now, it’s open season. Let’s put the idea of gender discrimination to bed once and for all. They handed us a winnable case.
(on the mission) Then we'll win it. Griswold talks of Bozarth as if the young man weren’t the
You're sure he’s up to it.
Mr. Bozarth is a fine litigator. (to Bozarth) Tell him your idea.
We list the laws.
What laws?

All of ‘em. Every federal law that treats men and women differently. So the Court sees exactly the can of worms these folks are-- Griswold’s belly-laugh interrupts him. Until, looking bet Brown and Bozarth, Griswold realizes it’s not a joke. (CONTINUED )
Last I checked, the U.S. Code was 20,000 pages long. (to Brown) Whose gonna read it? Him?
I can get it done, sir. All I need is an introduction. Griswold’s interest is piqued.
To whom? Bozarth knows exactly how outrageous it sounds:
... The Secretary of Defense.
Sprawling. It dwarfs the Washington Monument in the dista

Reels of magnetic tape spin. Glowing switches CLACK. And whole room HUMS. A KEYPUNCH OPERATOR (female, 22) hands a of punch cards to one of a dozen TECHNICIANS (male). Through plate glass, Brown and Bozarth watch from a hallw
And this computer will find what we're looking for?
In just a few days.
Without any human being actually reading the laws. ... What a horrifying age.
The Students are filing out. Talking among themselves. Murmuring their thanks and goodbye. SEE: Roemer, Burton, Valentin, Parker, Bennett amongst them... (CONTINUED )
Thank you, Professor. ..... Good night. ... Thank you. Good night. ... Thanks, .... That was a persuasive Professor Ginsburg. analysis of Gruenwald v Gardner, Mr. Bennett.
Hey thanks, Professor G.
Ruth Bader Ginsburg? Everyone stops to see him standing in the doorway with a thick envelope in hand.
Delivery from the Department of Justice. She signs for it and accepts. Then opens the envelope -- eyes on her:
It’s the government’s response brief.

Twenty volumes of THE U.S. CODE stacked around the room. and empty cartons from the ACLU... Ruth, Jane and Ruth’s students Roemer and Burton are seat AROUND THE DINING ROOM TABLE. In the middle of them, the brief is open to “Appendix E”. Each has a volume before h and is looking from the Appendix to her book, searching f the corresponding page.
Get this: there’s a law that we’re not allowed to fly military cargo planes?
Why would you want to?
That’s not the point. We should be allowed.
You really think you can change all these laws? (CONTINUED )
That’s the plan. The FRONT DOOR opens, and Martin enters. Dry cleaning ove his shoulder.
Ruth are you ready? Curtain’s up in forty minutes. It’d be nice to get there on time. (to himself) For a change. He enters the DINING ROOM.
What are you doing?
The Government's brief came. ... Look who's listed as co-author. She passes it to him.
I had heard Griswold was trying to recruit Brown to the DOJ. I guess it worked. ... How does it look?
Check out Appendix E. Martin gives her a look: Who are you? ... But obliges.
It’s every federal law that discriminates on the basis of sex. We’re looking them all up. Martin exhales: The scope of it.
Pass me one of those volumes. Ruth smiles as Martin joins the unorthodox team at the ta
How in the world did they manage all this?
A formal room. Out the window, the first hints of spring. (CONTINUED)

79 James Bozarth stands before A PULL-DOWN SCREEN in a forma wood-panelled “library.” Amidst a team of young DOJ LAWYE PROJECTED ON SCREEN: JUDGE DAUGHERTY (57, close-cropped h and perfect posture). OFF TO THE SIDE: Harriet Griswold (67 now and ina wheelchair) is supervising a MAID preparing tea service. ON A COUCH before Bozarth are Griswold and Brown.
So you're confident Daugherty will see it our way.
Based on reading all of his opinions. Yes. And so will Holloway. Bozarth uses his clicker. JUDGE HOLLOWAY (48, a kindly sm appears on the screen.
But the final judge, Doyle... Bozarth puts up DOYLE’s picture (60, a shock of white hai
He’s a tougher nut to crack. Griswold shoots Brown a warning look.
That’s unacceptable.
We need an unanimous verdict out of the Tenth Circuit, James.
I don’t intend to risk so-called gender discrimination going before the Supreme Court.
Yes... Yes, sir. I understand. Harriet can see he’s nervous. And sympathizes...
What makes this judge so difficult? (CONTINUED )

He’s a civil rights crusader, Ma’am. Two years ago he ordered Denver to bus black students to white schools. There was arson, protests, demands for him to quit the bench. But even after someone threw a bomb at his house, Doyle wouldn’t budge.
In that case he was enforcing the law. The Ginsburgs are asking him to MAKE law. We need to drive home the difference. Brown considerd Griswold’s challenge... And offers a path

(to Bozarth) Paint the judges a picture of the America that will exist if they rule the wrong way. Children running home from school to find... No one’s there. Mommy’s at the office. Or on a factory floor.
That's very good, Ernie. If a man and woman vie for the same job, she can work for less. What is a man without a paycheck to take care of his family?
What woman would want him?
(going with their flow) Wages go down. Divorce rates soar. Society unravels.
Exactly! The other side wants this to be about the Equal Protection Principle. YOU need to show the court that what’s really at stake is the American family.
What the judges are deciding is what kind of country, what kind of society, they want their children and grandchildren to grow up in.
INT. GRISWOLD’'S SUBURBAN HOME - BEDROOM - NIGHT Harriet’s atop the bed. Her withered legs sprawled limply across Griswold’s lap. He’s massaging them. She watches him for a beat...
Erwin. Did you ever take a caregiver deduction on our taxes?
I take whatever deductions the law says we're entitled to. He can see in her look, she’s not satisfied with his answ (CONTINUED )
81 GRISWOLD (CONT’D) Harriet...
Are you sure you’re doing the right thing in this case?
What exactly are you concerned about?
I don’t doubt the law is on your side. But I feel sorry for this Moritz. Can you imagine coping with the burden of my polio if--
You have NEVER been a burden to me. You have been so productive all your life.
But I’ve always had help. He knows it. Griswold considers her. After a long beat...

I can’t imagine how Charles Moritz Manages. It must take remarkable fortitude. Really. ... But I don’t get to indulge in sentiment. I took an oath to protect the constitution because it protects the country. I can’t let these Ginsburgs attack it piece-by-piece.
I don’t envy you. He smiles. And goes back to rubbing her legs.
You should. I’m a very lucky man.
Martin, in his usual golf shirt and French apron, is cook IN THE KITCHEN. James is drawing dinosaurs on THE COUNTER BETWEEN THE KIT AND DINING ROOM. (CONTINUED )
82 IN THE DINING ROOM: Ruth paces. Notes in hand. Practicing

(to herself) Sex and race are both unalterable biological traits... She's forgetting something. She checks her notes: Of cour IN THE KITCHEN: Martin lifts a flambé pan warming on the stove. And... WHOOSH! He ignites the Calvados inside.
(running into the kitchen) Whoa! Cool! Martin pours the flaming liquor over a pan of chicken liv THE DOORBELL RINGS. As Ruth goes to answer it, Jane finds her...
Mom. Can I be on the jury?

There is no jury in federal appeals court. No witnesses, no evidence. «+. It’s just you and the judges. She looks to Jane and smiles. Then opens THE FRONT DOOR t GERALD GUNTHER (44). He’s genial, with graying hair and a bald crown. He wears a collared shirt and gray sweater. R is delighted to see him.
Gerry. Jane, you remember my old professor, Gerald Gunther. He has a vaguely European accent. As Ruth takes his coat:
A little specificity, Mrs. Ginsburg. Former professor. (to Jane) Look at you. All grown up. Jane smiles. As he follows them into the DINING ROOM:
Hello, James.
(back to drawing) Hi. (CONTINUED )
What do you think of our courtroom? The place has been transformed into a rough facsimile of courtroom. The table serves as a judges’ bench. A diction lectern, the lawyer’s podium.
All it’s missing is Justice holding her scales. So, who did Mel find to be the third judge?
(intimidated) Pauli Murray.
He’s not making it easy for you.
Who’s Pauli Murray?
Thurgood Marshall himself called Pauli’s writings the Bible of the Civil Rights Movement. Martin enters, wielding a meat tenderizer.
Gerry. I come bearing your gavel.

Beneath a drawing (by James) of Justice, the moot-court judges sit behind the dining room table. Laid out on the table: sliced baguette, apple, vegetables And a heaping, garnished platter of chicken liver paté. Gerry BANGS his meat tenderizer gavel. Mel is to his left. Biting into a baguette slice topped w paté, he’s impressed. To Gerry’s right is PAULI MURRAY (61) -- a petite, black woman with short hair in tight curls and round glasses. H grin extenuated by joyous laugh lines. Martin watches from the couch. With Jane. (CONTINUED )
Counsel for the appellant, you may proceed. Again. Ruth, at the lectern, takes a breath. As the “judges” continue to snack.
Your honors and may it please the court. Section 214 of the tax code covers employed single women who care for their dependents. But excludes Charles Moritz, a bachelor providing--
My wife stays home to raise our children. You’re saying she’s oppressed?
No Judge. But as a man, you--
Stop. Stop. (he finishes chewing) Never make it about the judge.
You don’t think the judge knows he’s a man?
I don’t think she needs to put him on the defensive about it.
In Brown, we put it out there without apology: This. Is. Wrong.
Well, no offense, but Ruth doesn’t exactly have Thurgood Marshall’s......
Balls?
Gravitas. Nothing resolved, the conversation’s over. Ruth shuffles papers to cover her frustration. Jane gives Martin a worr look. His smile says “Don’t worry.” (CONTINUED )
Should I start again?
Ya think?
Whenever you’re ready.

Your honors and may it please the court. Section 214 of the tax code covers employed single women who care for their dependents. But excludes Charles Moritz, a bachelor providing the same care. There is no rational basis for--
Why isn’t it rational? Men go out. Women stay home. That’s been the way of things for thousands of years. Ruth takes a breath. Keeps her cool.
Historical justification was also used to legitimize the separation of the races. Now classification--
You're saying race and gender are the same?
Both are unalterable biological traits of--
This nation struggles to give blacks fair representation throughout society.
(to Gunther) Would you pass the... Ruth watches Gunther pass the paté. (CONTINUED )
(still going) ...Are you saying that, if we decide in your client’s favor, we're committing ourselves to working toward half our, I don’t know... firemen being women? Half our nurses being men?
Why shouldn’t men be nurses? If women want to fight fires-—-
What about pilots?
Again if women--
(chewing) Judges?
Why not?
Generals? CEOs? What about garbage men? You wanna be a garbage man?
And men should be teachers or raise children, if they want. Percentages aren’t the point.
No. Wrong. Wrong. You’re People should be able to screwing it up! pursue their passions and-- She holds up the Government’s APPENDIX E:

Have you seen the appendix attached to their brief? Laws written by men who think we're privileged to be excused from men’s obligations. It’s not a privilege. It’s a cage. These laws are the bars. As they all fall silent. Ruth realizes she’s blown it. Me eyes her smugly... (CONTINUED )
(smearing paté onto bread) And you're going to take on all of them at once, is that it?
You asked the questions.
(harshly) That doesn’t mean you answer them, Ruth. You’re making the government’s case for them. Jane's surprised, and angered, by his tone.
Either you make this case about one man, or you lose. Because to the judges, you're not talking about women in the abstract. You’re talking about their wives. At home. Baking briskets.
You braise a brisket. You don’t bake it. Mel shoots her a look. As Martin chuckles.
Perhaps that’s enough, Mel.

No. I don’t think it is, Gerry. (to Ruth) Mel bites Since you were a girl, you’ve been pretty and smart as a whip. But you're coming off as some bitter, unlikable shrew I don’t recognize. And let me tell you: if that’s who shows up in Denver, Ruth, you’1l blow it. And would it kill you to smile?
That's your sage advice: ignore the judges and smile? into the bread. With his mouth full:
But I will say your paté is the best I’ve ever tasted. (CONTINUED )
88 Ruth’s look says, Choke on it. Martin rises and approaches Ruth. Gently. Supportive. An excellent teacher, he talks just to her...

You could evade. (modelling) “Do you think women should be firefighters?” ... I’ve never considered it. Because my client isn’t a firefighter. Jane's watching. Martin’s “teaching” Ruth, but without condescension. Wanting only her success. Ruth listens. Wi trust and affection. It’s intimate... And Jane is affecte
